prompts.prompt: Can you check if the code examples in this JavaScript closure article actually work correctly? I'm seeing some outputs that don't match what's written in the comments.
I wrote a blog post about JavaScript promises and want to make sure all my MDN links are working and point to the right pages before I publish it.
Help me verify that this explanation of typeof behavior is actually correct according to the ECMAScript specification. I want to make sure I'm not spreading misinformation.
I'm about to publish a JavaScript tutorial and need someone to check that all the external resources I'm linking to are still accessible and actually cover what I say they cover.
Can you run through this article about JavaScript event loops and flag any technical claims that might be inaccurate or misleading? I'm worried about perpetuating common misconceptions.
I need to fact-check this comprehensive guide on JavaScript hoisting - verify the code examples work, check that MDN references are correct, and make sure I'm not teaching any outdated patterns.
Before I submit this PR for the JavaScript concepts repository, can you run the tests and make sure my new content about async/await doesn't contain any factual errors?

I'm reviewing a community contribution about JavaScript type coercion and need help verifying that all the comparison examples produce the outputs they claim, plus checking if any statements contradict the ECMAScript spec.
Can you check this JavaScript article for common misconceptions like 'objects are passed by reference' or '=== is always faster than =='? I want to make sure I'm teaching accurate information.

I need a complete accuracy audit of this JavaScript fundamentals page - code verification, link checking, spec compliance, resource validation, and a detailed report of any issues found with recommended fixes.
